entry.et: Middle English, probably of Scandinavian origin; akin to Old Norse bakki bank; akin to Old English benc bench bench

def.dt: :a mound, pile, or ridge raised above the surrounding level: as
:a piled-up mass of cloud or fog
:an undersea elevation rising especially from the continental shelf
:the rising ground bordering a lake, river, or sea or forming the edge of a cut or hollow
:a steep slope (as of a hill)
:the lateral inward tilt of a surface along a curve or of a vehicle (as an airplane) when turning
:a protective or cushioning rim or piece
:to raise a bank about
:to cover (as a fire) with fresh fuel and adjust the draft of air so as to keep in an inactive state
:to build (a curve) with the roadbed or track inclined laterally upward from the inside edge
:to heap or pile in a bank
:to drive (a ball in billiards) into a cushion
:to bounce (a ball or shot) off a surface (as a backboard) into or toward a goal bank in a rebound
:to form or group in a tier
:to rise in or form a bank often used with up clouds would bank up about midday, and showers fall William Beebe
:to incline an airplane laterally
:to incline laterally
:to follow a curve or incline skiers banking around the turn

entry.et: Middle English, from Middle French or Old Italian; Middle French banque, from Old Italian banca, literally, bench, of Germanic origin; akin to Old English benc

def.dt: :an establishment for the custody, loan, exchange, or issue of money, for the extension of credit, and for facilitating the transmission of funds
:the table, counter, or place of business of a money changer
:a person conducting a gambling house or game
:dealer
:a supply of something held in reserve: as
:the fund of supplies (as money, chips, or pieces) held by the banker or dealer for use in a game
:a fund of pieces belonging to a game (as dominoes) from which the players draw
:a place where something is held available memory banks
:a depot for the collection and storage of a biological product a blood bank
:to manage a bank
:to deposit money or have an account in a bank
:to deposit or store in a bank
:to depend or rely on can always bank on her friendship

entry.et: Middle English banc bench, from Anglo-French, of Germanic origin; akin to Old English benc

def.dt: :a group or series of objects arranged together in a row or a tier: as
:a set of elevators
:a row or tier of telephones
:one of the horizontal and usually secondary or lower divisions of a headline
:a card (as a credit card or an ATM card) issued by a bank
:the interest discounted in advance on a note and computed on the face value of the note
:legal holiday
:a period when banks in general are closed often by government fiat
:a medium of exchange consisting chiefly of checks and drafts
:a shot in billiards and pool in which a player banks the cue ball or the object ball
:a shot in basketball played to rebound from the backboard into the basket
